content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A spring-loaded launcher can be securely attached to a tabletop. When the spring is at its uncompressed length, the plunger is in the position shown above in Figure 1. A small wood block can be pressed against the end of the plunger, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown in Figure 2. When the block is released, the plunger pushes the block along the tabletop. Two pins are attached to the edge of the table to prevent the plunger from extending beyond the table. When the plunger hits the pins, the block then leaves the table. There is nonnegligible friction between the block and the tabletop. The launcher can be moved closer to or farther from the edge of the tabletop. Students set up tables 1 and 2, as shown above, with tabletops that are made of the same material. On table 1, which is taller than table 2, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="S equals A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is slightly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On table 2, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="s equals B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is significantly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On both tables, the block is released from rest and loses contact with the plunger at the moment the plunger reaches the pins. <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the spring constant of the spring. <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the mass of the block. <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance the spring is compressed. <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu) is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the tabletop. <math alttext="s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop. Assume the spring is ideal, the plunger has negligible mass, the block loses contact with the plunger immediately after it reaches the end of the table, and there is non-negligible friction between the tabletops and the blocks. (a) Without manipulating equations, explain why the block launched from table 2 could have a greater speed when it leaves the table than the block launched from table 1 does.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A spring-loaded launcher can be securely attached to a tabletop. When the spring is at its uncompressed length, the plunger is in the position shown above in Figure 1. A small wood block can be pressed against the end of the plunger, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown in Figure 2. When the block is released, the plunger pushes the block along the tabletop. Two pins are attached to the edge of the table to prevent the plunger from extending beyond the table. When the plunger hits the pins, the block then leaves the table. There is nonnegligible friction between the block and the tabletop. The launcher can be moved closer to or farther from the edge of the tabletop. Students set up tables 1 and 2, as shown above, with tabletops that are made of the same material. On table 1, which is taller than table 2, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="S equals A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is slightly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On table 2, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="s equals B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is significantly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On both tables, the block is released from rest and loses contact with the plunger at the moment the plunger reaches the pins. <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the spring constant of the spring. <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the mass of the block. <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance the spring is compressed. <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu) is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the tabletop. <math alttext="s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop. Assume the spring is ideal, the plunger has negligible mass, the block loses contact with the plunger immediately after it reaches the end of the table, and there is non-negligible friction between the tabletops and the blocks. (a) Without manipulating equations, explain why the block launched from table 2 could have a greater speed when it leaves the table than the block launched from table 1 does.
(b) Does the block launched from table 2 spend more, less, or the same amount of time in the air than the block launched from table 1 does? Explain your reasoning.

(c) Consider the system consisting of only the block. Determine the change, if any, in the total mechanical energy of the system from the instant the block leaves the table to the instant immediately before it reaches the ground.

The students correctly derive an equation for the speed v of the block when it is at the edge of the tabletop, in terms of <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (the distance between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop):<math alttext="v equals the square root of, the fraction k over m, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, 2 L s minus s squared, close parenthesis, minus 2 mu g s, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.(d) Does this equation for <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> support your argument from part (a) that the block launched from table 2 could have a larger speed when it leaves the table than the block on table 1 does? Briefly explain why or why not.

(e) The students now repeat the scenario with identical setups except that the coefficient of kinetic friction between the blocks and the table is larger. Does this change in the coefficient of friction make it more likely or less likely that the block launched from table 1 has a greater speed when it leaves the table than the block on table 2 does? Briefly explain your reasoning.

(f) Two students each try to sketch a graph of the horizontal position and speed of the block as a function of time while the block is being pushed by the plunger. Their graphs are shown above. In which pair of graphs are the two graphs consistent with each other? Justify your selection.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
